image.title: The latest news from News Center.

item.title: A mile-deep campus
item.creator: leah
item.description: Forget wide-open spaces—this campus is in a former gold mine.
item.comment: Forget wide-open spaces—this campus is in a former gold mine.

item.title: Plug & Play Vehicle GPS for sale
item.creator: friend
item.description: MasTrack MT-OBD Live GPS Tracker, 30 second installation. Plugs directly into your OBD port inside the vehicle, 2 units for $50 retail value $75 each. I used them for 6 months. Can be viewed from any internet browser. Perfect for tracking your teenage driver and or their driving habits. Small monthly fee for just the GPS portion. Contact: Don Friend at x2029, or friend@fnal.gov
item.comment: MasTrack MT-OBD Live GPS Tracker, 30 second installation. Plugs directly into your OBD port inside the vehicle, 2 units for $50 retail value $75 each. I used them for 6 months. Can be viewed from any internet browser. Perfect for tracking your teenage driver and or their driving habits. Small monthly fee for just the GPS portion. Contact:  Don Friend at x2029, or friend@fnal.gov

item.title: Gallery Series 2016 kicks off with Spektral Quartet
item.creator: mackay
item.description: On Sunday, January 24, the Spektral Quartet performed a program that included Prokofiev, Schumann, Beethoven, and two young composers — Sky Macklay and David Reminick — to a rapt audience as the kick-off concert for the 2016 Gallery Chamber Series.
item.comment:
On Sunday, January 24, the Spektral Quartet performed a program that included Prokofiev, Schumann, Beethoven, and two young composers — Sky Macklay and David Reminick — to a rapt audience as the kick-off concert for the 2016 Gallery Chamber Series. Visual artist Michele Thrane was also present.

Spektral Quartet

Spektral Quartet

item.title: Geese flee at bison barn
item.creator: Rashmi
item.description: Geese flee as Fermilab Herdsman Cleo Garcia drives through pasture to check up on the lab's bison.
item.comment: Geese flee as Fermilab Herdsman Cleo Garcia drives through pasture to check up on the lab’s bison. Photo: Rashmi Shivni, OC

item.title: Anna Grassellino, Vladimir Shiltsev elected to APS Division of Particles and Beams executive committee
item.creator: annag
item.description: Scientists Anna Grassellino and Vladimir Shiltsev have been elected respectively member-at-large and vice chair for the American Physical Society Division of the Physics of Beams executive committee.
item.comment:
Anna Grassellino (left) of the Technical Division and Vladimir Shiltsev, head of the Accelerator Physics Center in the Accelerator Division, have been elected respectively member-at-large and vice chair for the American Physical Society Division of the Physics of Beams executive committee. They began their terms this month and will serve three-year terms.

Congratulations to our scientists.

item.title: Still for sale – give me an offer…
item.creator: mpierson
item.description: I still have my husband’s beautifully restored 1967 Ford Mustang Coupe for sale and would love to have my garage space back! This vehicle has full restoration and is newly painted black on black with a strong running rebuilt 289 motor that has less than 300 miles! Automatic transmission and more. Please call or email with the subject line “Interested in your ’67 Mustang” for more information and/or pictures. Contact: mel.pierson@hotmail.com or call (417) 214-6868.

item.title: Space heater recall and space heater safety
item.creator: asands
item.description: Check your offices and homes for a Vornado portable space heater. There is one Vornado space heater that has been recently recalled, and this type space heater was involved in a fire at a national laboratory. View the recall information and space heater safety information here: http://esh-docdb.fnal.gov/cgi-bin/ShowDocument?docid=3186
item.comment: Check your offices and homes for a Vornado portable space heater.  There is one Vornado space heater that has been recently recalled, and this type space heater was involved in a fire at a national laboratory.  View the recall information and space heater safety information here:  http://esh-docdb.fnal.gov/cgi-bin/ShowDocument?docid=3186

item.title: Particles and unparticles
item.creator: leah
item.description: CMS goes looking for unparticles and dark matter, studying events in which a Z boson was created, as well as undetected energy that would be the signal of either a dark matter particle or unparticle escaping.
item.comment:
Those of us of a certain age will remember an old advertising campaign for 7-Up that was touted as the “uncola.” Today’s article talks about a clever, but highly speculative, idea called the “unparticle.” Photo: Grant Hutchinson

The LHC accelerator is in the business of discovering new things, from particles that are expected (like the Higgs boson) to particles that are sort of expected (like the panoply of particles predicted by supersymmetric models) to particles from something entirely unexpected (like the what-the-heck-is-that moment that changes our theories forever).

The commonality of all of these potential discoveries is that they include particles. All particles have a fixed mass. So all electrons in the universe have the same mass, as do all muons, pions, protons or any other subatomic particle you can name.

(This is true no matter how fast the particles are moving, and it’s worth emphasizing this point, as it may not jibe with some readers’ understanding of what happens when a particle’s velocity approaches light speed. You may have heard that the mass of a particle changes as velocity increases. We teach this to people first encountering relativity, but the statement is an illustrative one. What actually changes is the particle’s inertia , which is equivalent to mass at low velocities. You can read more about this in a previous column . So, for a particle, no matter what energy and momentum it has, it must also have a single and specific mass.)

However, in 2007 scientist Howard Georgi had an idea: Suppose there was a kind of particle that had a mass that wasn’t constant. If you doubled the particle’s energy and momentum, you would double its mass. If you halved the energy, you’d halve the mass. Such a particle wouldn’t have a well-defined mass at all. This kind of particle is called an unparticle.

These physicists contributed to this analysis.

Unparticles are governed by fractal mathematics and are highly speculative. In fact, there is no hint in the data that they must exist, nor is there a compelling theoretical reason why they should. On the other hand, they are possible, and given that we don’t know what theory will supplant the Standard Model, we should be open to all sorts of improbable ideas. We do know that unparticles, if they exist, must interact via known forces only weakly.

So, of course, CMS went looking for them. In a recent analysis that looked for both unparticles and dark matter, scientists studied events in which a Z boson was created, as well as undetected energy that would be the signal of either a dark matter particle or unparticle escaping.

Sadly, no evidence was observed for either phenomenon. Truthfully, it would have been shocking if unparticles had been observed, but the fact that LHC experiments are looking for even such bizarre possibilities highlights that the scientific community is exploring all viable ideas, hoping to find something that gives us a huge advance in our understanding of the nature of reality.

item.title: Snowflakes by Lederman Science Center
item.creator: leah
item.description: These delicate snowflakes fell near the Lederman Science Center on Jan. 20.
